qas.question: What is one disease that has been nearly eradicated thanks to vaccines and antibiotics?

context: Antibiotics revolutionized medicine in the <a2_0><a5_0><a10_0><a14_0><b20_0>20th<a5_0/> century<b20_0/><a14_0/><a10_0/><a2_0/>, and have together with <a6_0><b22_0>vaccination<b22_0/><a6_0/> led to the near eradication of diseases such as <a0_0><a15_0><b18_0>tuberculosis<b18_0/><a15_0/><a0_0/> in the developed world. Their effectiveness and easy access led to <a1_0><b19_0>overuse, especially in <a16_0>livestock raising<a16_0/>, prompting bacteria to <a7_0><a11_0>develop resistance<a11_0/><a7_0/><a1_0/>.<b19_0/> This has led to widespread problems with <a17_0>antimicrobial and <a9_0>antibiotic resistance<a17_0/><a9_0/>, so much as to prompt the <a3_0><a8_0><a12_0><b21_0>World Health Organization<b21_0/><a12_0/><a8_0/><a3_0/> to classify antimicrobial resistance as a "serious threat [that] is no longer a prediction for the future, it is happening right now in <a13_0>every region of the world<a13_0/> and has the potential to affect <a4_0>anyone, of any age, in any country<a4_0/>".
